p: The incidence of HCV-associated glomerular disease is low and this makes it difficult to conduct clinical trials to control the disease [ 3]. Renal disease is now considered an important cause of morbidity and mortality in MC vasculitis induced by HCV [ 3]. Treatment of HCV has made considerable progress with the recent introduction of IFN-free combinations of DAAs which increased dramatically the rates of viral clearance [ 3]. The purpose of this review is to report the most important data concerning the treatment of HCV-related glomerular disease, an important extra-hepatic complication of HCV infection.
